awd_titl_txt: SpecEES: Collaborative Research: Stochastic Geometry Meets Channel Measurements: Comprehensive Modeling, Analysis,Fundamental Design-tradeoffs in Real-world Massive-MIMO Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
One promising solution to handle the ever-increasing demand for wireless capacity is to deploy significantly higher number of antenna elements at the base station compared to the number of users in the cell. This so called Massive MIMO approach creates extra degrees of freedom that can be used to "shape" beams, thus enhancing both the energy and spectral efficiency of communication links. Massive MIMO can be implemented in a variety of ways. One extreme is the concentrated implementation in which hundreds of antennas are deployed at a single location within a cell. On the other extreme is the fully distributed implementation in which hundreds of single-antenna remote radio heads, distributed throughout the cell, are connected to a common baseband processing unit, thus forming a distributed base station. In between these extremes is the relatively less-investigated case of semi-distributed implementation in which multi-antenna remote radio heads are distributed across the cell. While the massive MIMO idea has been around for several years now, our understanding of the performance of these systems is still limited. This is mainly due to the lack of real-world propagation models (especially for the semi-distributed implementations) as well as mathematical tools that can expose performance trends for different spatial distributions of the users and base stations, both of which are known to significantly impact the performance of these systems. The main goal of this research is to develop a transformative measurements-driven analytical approach to enable the efficient deployment of massive MIMO networks ultimately leading to better customer experience, via improved spectral efficiency, and greener wireless communications, via improved energy efficiency. All the key outcomes of this project will be widely disseminated through publications, tutorials, and industry collaborations. 

The proposed research will develop a comprehensive measurement-driven approach to the spectral and energy efficiency analyses of massive MIMO systems by blending ideas from multiple disciplines, such as communication theory, stochastic geometry, point process theory, and propagation modeling, yielding the following key innovations: (1) stochastic geometry-aware spectral and energy efficiency metrics to facilitate fundamental analysis and fair comparison across different flavors of massive MIMO, (2) new stochastic geometry approaches to the coverage analysis of concentrated, distributed, and semi-distributed massive MIMO systems, (3) new results on the channel characterization for distributed massive MIMO systems under different classes of propagation models, (4) extensive measurement campaign (tailored to massive MIMO systems) using a one-of-its-kind channel sounder, (5) fundamentally new channel models for semi-deterministic massive MIMO setups that will incorporate correlation of the pathloss and dispersion metrics, in addition to traditionally modeled correlation of the shadowing from user to different RRHs, and (6) new massive-MIMO channel models for the millimeter-wave frequencies. This project will thus combine the powerful spatial modeling tools from stochastic geometry with real-world massive MIMO channel models to compare and contrast the performance of different flavors of massive MIMO under real-world operational constraints, which will directly impact the design, operation, and management of future cellular networks.

por.por_cntn:
One of the hallmarks of wireless communications is the constantly increasing need for data throughput, caused on one hand by the increase in the number of users and devices that want to communicate wirelessly, and on the other hand by the increased requirement for data rate that each user is consuming. This increased data throughput requirement creates enormous challenges for the network, because spectrum is limited; thus the spectral efficiency of the wireless systems need to be increased. One of the most promising methods for improving spectral efficiency is the use of base stations with large number of antennas, also known as “massive MIMO” (when the antennas of one base station are all co-located at a site, we speak of “concentrated massive MIMO”; if they are distributed over many locations, we are speaking of “distributed massive MIMO”). The goal of this project, which was done in collaboration with Virginia Tech, was to investigate massive MIMO through a combination of stochastic geometry analysis and measurement of propagation channels. The main goal was to create a more realistic framework for the analysis and optimization of such systems, thus providing the possibility for better throughput, reliability, and energy efficiency of such systems.

 

The performance of massive MIMO systems are fundamentally determined by the propagation channels in which they operate, yet many aspects of those channels were unknown. We thus set out to create new channel sounders, perform measurements, and create channel models based on those measurements. In this pursuit we established novel paradigms of how such measurements can be done efficiently. Under normal circumstances, each AP needs its own fiber backhaul, limiting the number of measured APs to about 10. We developed a sounder based on a transmitter mounted on a drone that can be sent to the required locations with little effort, enabling measurements at tens of thousands of AP locations.

 

Based on our measurement results, we could show that traditional channel models are not  well suited for distributed massive MIMO systems in urban environments (where they are most needed) since they assume that the channel (as seen from a handset) is independent of the direction one looks at. But when looking down a street canyon, the channel actually looks quite different than when the handset turns looks directly at the house that is part of the canyon. Based on measurements, augmented by computer simulations, we developed a novel channel model that is more realistic.

 

Another important area of investigation was the reduction of overhead for pilot signals. Massive MIMO systems need to know the downlink channel (channel to the handset) so that they can correctly form beams pointing towards them. Traditionally, this requires the base station to send out pilots, and the handsets to send back channel estimates based on those pilots; this process has a large overhead. In the literature, an alternative method had been suggested where the base station estimates the downlink channels based on its own measurement of uplink channels (which greatly reduces the overhead). We derived the theoretical limits of the accuracy that can be achieved with this method, and furthermore confirmed the results experimentally. The results serve as a benchmark for practical algorithms that will be developed/implemented in the future. This is particularly relevant for 5G cellular systems, where the overhead for the above-mentioned feedback can become very significant.

 

Finally, we investigated how power control at both handsets and APs impact the spectral efficiency in distributed massive MIMO systems. Having every device or AP transmit at full power is not optimum, both from an energy point of view (which is important both for making wireless communications greener, and for battery lifetime and thus user satisfaction), and from a spectral efficiency point of view, because more transmit energy might create more interference. We investigated a number of power control algorithms with respect to their spectral efficiency and energy efficiency in measured channels, thus allowing a realistic assessment. We also analyzed what distributed MIMO configuration (number of antennas per AP) works best.

 

From a broader impact point of view, the project has enabled the students working on it to experience interdisciplinary work, ranging from deep theory and signal processing to measurements and channel modeling, and to learn collaborative techniques. The project also provided a number of undergraduate and master’s students with their first research experience. Special emphasis was placed on recruiting female and URM students. In terms of general impact, our contributions help to improve both data throughput and spectral efficiency, as well as energy efficiency, of massive MIMO systems, which are a core component of 5G and Beyond 5G. Since such systems are an integral part of modern life, both for industry and for individual consumers, the impact of any of the results of this project will ripple through applications from smart cities to high-quality video streaming.
